11:10 am
PM

Was Mark Williams Chief China Economist at Cap Economics one of those?

PM

PM

But here's what he's saying now

11:11 am
PM

China’s equity markets continue to tumble, its currency is under unprecedented pressure and Chinese
policymakers’ reputation for competence is looking ever more tarnished. Contrary to many of the
headlines though, the economic data show no sign of major deterioration in recent months.
 There is little doubt that China’s economy is growing at a much slower rate now than in the recent past.
According to our China Activity Proxy, the economy grew by roughly 4.5% y/y last quarter, compared
with 7% a little over two years before. On these grounds, investors have reason to be downbeat. But
there is no sign of the more recent, deeper slowdown many argue must lie behind the stock market
falls and capital outflows. Indeed, much of the slowdown seems to have occurred a year or more ago.

PM

In the chart below we compare growth rates from the first half of 2015 with those for October and
November (the latest available) for a selection of indicators covering major parts of the economy. For the
most part they show that growth at the end of 2015 was little changed from average growth recorded
in the first half of the year, when the stock market was still rising. Our forecasts suggest that headline
growth rates for December will be slightly weaker than those for November (see our latest China Watch
for details) but not by enough to change the broad picture.
 In signalling that growth has remained stable, the chart also suggests both that the slumps in the stock
market in the middle of 2015 and again this month were not caused by any worsening of economic
conditions and also that last year’s equity collapse didn’t itself cause activity to slow. The one indicator
below that looks weaker now than in early 2015 is exports, a gauge of foreign demand.

PM

We’ve displayed in the chart the most high profile activity and demand indicators that analysts follow
each month. With some justification, many might question whether they can be trusted. For this reason,
we’ve added our China Activity Proxy (CAP) and a measure of exports from the US, EU and Japan to
China, based on those countries’ official data. Both should be less susceptible to manipulation than
more closely watched Chinese data. The broad picture though is much the same.
 In sum, growth on these different measures is much slower than a few years ago and in some cases
(notably trade) looks particularly depressed. But there is no support in the data for the notion of a
deepening economic crisis. China’s financial markets are in turmoil, but the same can’t be said of the
economy.

BE

Time is of the essence for Anglo American, in our view. The company’s strategy, as
articulated in the December CMD presentation, is essentially the right one -
shrinking the business into c.20 assets (including 12 “engine room” assets) that could
probably weather further deterioration in commodity pricing. However, lack of detail on
timing and the quantum of unlocked value leave the shares vulnerable and the market
appears impatient. If the company is to avoid acceleration of what is essentially an
equity to debt story with potentially significant implications for equity value, then
management need to act, in our view. In this note we have attempted to estimate the
value uplift from pursuing the CMD strategy using spot prices – 42pps. We have then
looked at a scenario that could expedite the process in our view and create value, which
is to unbundle the entire Anglo American South Africa (AASA), a company that is
already a defined legal entity in its own right. This would, in our view, then allow the
company to approach shareholders to participate in an equity raise, which, if big
enough (we estimate c.$7bn), could reverse the likely decline in credit rating, attract
interest from value investors both institutional and corporate, and generally set the
company on a stronger footing.
The CMD base case. Our asset by asset analysis of the company’s strategy to shrink the
business into 20 operations, including the 12 engine room mines, suggests that they
could realize $811m from asset sales (assuming parity with NPV). The remaining c.35
operations are to be disposed – the core of which we estimate to have a negative NPV
of $1.4bn. This process would take the total NPV of the group on spot pricing from
$4.3bn, or 225p, to $5.7bn, or c.300p pre closure costs. If we estimate the latter to be
$600m, that reduces to 267p, in line with the current share price. There would be little
shrinkage in EBITDA under this scenario and the core should generate c.$3bn using
spot. However, there would be virtually no change to the net debt position and timing
and price uncertainty would leave the company share price vulnerable, in our view.
The AASA alternative (or closing the SOTP discount): Carving out the South African
operations could be an attractive alternative, something management has looked at
(and dismissed) in the past under the helm of Cynthia Carroll, with shareholders in
Anglo American receiving shares in two companies. 2 of the 12 “engine room” assets
(Mogalakwena and Venetia) sit within the AASA but that would be tolerable, in our
view. It would remove all SA issues and shrink the workforce by 75000 (from 135k). Yes
there would be flowback issues and approval would be needed, but we believe there is
much more upside from this prior to an equity issue and this should allow the company
to at least approach shareholders for assistance in fortifying the balance sheet.
Time is of the essence: Whichever route is chosen, and we see only a small chance of the
latter, the company needs to act. The unencumbered liquidity from the RCF, which expires
in 2020, may appear to buy them time; however last year’s share price performance
suggests to us this is an illusion. We move our PT to 225p and remain Underweight.

PM

As the Xmas trading statement season rolls on

BE

Hm.

11:33 am
PM

Here's INvestec's take on Xmas updates so far

PM

An eventful first week, with the biggest stories arguably the rejected bid for Home Retail and at least 4 new CEOs in 2016, rather than the weather and continuing shift of spend online. Weather has had a major impact on spending patterns, particularly in apparel, reflected in a de-rating of the sector. We summarise below the main themes for 2016, namely: management change, strength of cashflow, discounting and the ongoing shift online.

PM

2016 will see (at least) 4 new CEOs with Steve Rowe heading up M&S and Karen Hubbard Card Factory, in addition to Debenhams and Bonmarché, where we await news on succession.
Strength of sector’s cashflow could result in further corporate activity, though the sector doesn’t naturally lend itself to M&A. News that there had been a bid for Home Retail is not a surprise, in our view, given its low valuation,, balance sheet strength and cashflow, though the fact it was Sainsbury was. The press is suggesting a bid of over 200p may be needed; we view Thursday’s trading update as an important milestone for HOME and Argos’s turnaround.

11:33 am
PM

Weather was a feature, for the third Christmas in a row & particularly hit the apparel retailers. Even NEXT reported a sales shortfall relative to expectations. SportsDirect (N/R) took the number of profit warnings to 3, joining Game Digital (N/R) & Bonmarché pre-Christmas, with Poundland arguably also a warning given the scale of forecast cuts in its November and January updates.
Black Friday has certainly changed the shape of Christmas trading, but its full impact is more difficult to quantify given the warm weather. Its establishment has deepened a promotional culture (BRC’s December non-food deflation was 3%), which is not seen as positive for the industry in our view.

PM

Shift online continues at pace, as can be seen from the likes of Johnlewis.com sales being up 25% over the 6 weeks (with online 40% of JL sales), and M&S +21%, for example. It will be interesting to see what has happened at an industry level when the BRC data is published on Tuesday.
Stock picking key, in our view, with rising interest rates a possibility. Historically, the General Retail sector underperforms in a rising rate environment, though it has already been sold off aggressively and is more cash generative nowadays. Our Top Picks are retail roll-out stories where we see scope for upgrades, namely JD Sports (TP 1100p), SuperGroup (TP 1850p) & boohoo (TP 46p) as well as M&S (TP 570p) for self-help & potential to return more cash. Other picks: Halfords (TP 460p), a value play which may join the list of surplus cash returners; Majestic Wine (400p TP) - a recovery story; and Home Retail (TP 155p) - a high risk/reward recovery story. B&M’s (TP 370p) recent weakness offers an attractive entry point with concerns over current trading overdone in our view.

PM

And for this week...

11:34 am
PM

Tuesday: boohoo & Debenhams; Wednesday: Dunelm (N/R), ‘Super’ Thursday: ASOS, Home, JD & SuperGroup; and Friday Bonmarché.

PM

Home on Thursday

11:45 am
BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Cautious trading update, reducing EBITDA forecasts by 9%. Sports Direct
has released a trading statement stating that as a result of worsening
trading conditions on the High Street and unseasonal weather over the key
Christmas trading period, it is no longer confident of meeting its £420mn
underlying EBITDA target for FY16. We think the two weeks before Xmas
and the week after have been much tougher than expected in the UK
and Europe, particularly Austria which is a winter sports business. Around
40% of Sports Direct's sales come from apparel with 40% from footwear
and 20% from equipment. It is now guiding to EBITDA of £380-420mn
which we think will largely depend on the level of full price sales until
April. We think inventory clearance will impact SPD's margin but at least
temperatures have fallen now in major markets. To be prudent we now
forecast £386mn EBITDA for FY16 with £420mn for FY17.
Bonus scheme may be invalidated. Assuming that Sports Direct now
doesn't achieve its £420mn EBITDA target, this would mean that it would
save the costs of the bonus scheme from year three onwards. However
the concern here is that staff morale is affected and staff turnover rises,
which in recent years has been close to half the industry average.
Stronger event calendar in FY17 but also cost headwinds. SPD should still
benefit from a more favourable sporting calendar eg there is strong home
nation representation in Euro 2016 and Austria have qualified for the first
time. Also SPD has bought out the remaining 50% of Irish department
store chain Heatons. Together we think these could add £20mn EBITDA in
FY17. However SPD also faces margin headwinds from the stronger USD
on purchasing and from the minimum wage, on which it recently raised its
guidance by £10mn. We expect SPD to follow the big third party brands in
raising prices but this may impact volumes going forward.
Valuation undemanding but lacking catalysts; negative read for other
discounters Primark, H&M and B&M. On our revised estimates SPD now
trades at just c.10x cal. 16 P/E, however it does not pay a dividend and
shareholders may have to wait a while for more positive news on trading
including International. As such we retain our Sector Perform rating on
the shares. We view the statement as a negative readacross for other
discounters like ABF (Primark) which reports on Jan 14, H&M which
reports on Jan 15 and B&M which reports on Jan 22.

BE

Oh, and should note this extraordinary story I think that was broken by the Times.

11:45 am
BE

Mike Ashley sued over ‘broken £15m deal agreed in pub’

BE

http://www.thetime...article4660382.ece

BE

During the course of a two-and-a-half hour drinking session in the Horse and Groom pub in Great Portland Street, London, in 2013, Mike Ashley agreed to “incentivise” Jeff Blue, a former Merrill Lynch banker, to repair Sports Direct’s relationship with the City, it is claimed.

The claim that Mr Ashley conjured up a multimillion-pound incentive to boost the share price of the company over a drink in a pub will raise further concerns about the maverick retailer’s business practices, especially coming the day after the company warned on profits.

11:47 am
BE

In a court document denying the claims, Mr Ashley admitted “a considerable amount of alcohol” was drunk that night but said that any conversation was just “banter” and denied that any agreement was made.

BE

According to the High Court claim, the retail billionaire agreed to pay Mr Blue if he could double Sports Direct’s share price from just under £4 to £8, increasing the value of Mr Ashley’s stake by about £1.6 billion.

In Mr Blue’s account of the deal, which is contested by Mr Ashley, it was claimed that the Sports Direct founder said: “What should I do to incentivise Jeff? If he can get the stock to £8 per share why should I give a f**k how much I have to pay him [...] I will have made so much money it doesn’t matter.”

PM

It's a good story

11:47 am
BE

It's a brilliant story.

BE

Though it'd set a troubling precedent if everyone it going to be held to what they promised while in the pub.

undefined
11:49 am
BE

Let's find some sellside to fill the time from here.

BE

Merrill upgrades Whitbread, which has been awful for a few months.

BE

(And attracts some lively emails every time I write about it, accusing me of all sorts.)

11:51 am
BE

Here's the gist of the Merrill note.

BE

• We raise from Neutral to Buy with unchanged PO 5080p (Feb17E PE 20x).
• Consensus expectations now look more conservative and, the valuation less frothy.
• Growth strategy intact = double digit EPS and DPS growth deriving c.15% TSR.

BE

25% off its highs, fundamental growth story intact
With the shares well off their highs, consensus expectations looking more conservative,
the fundamental growth story still low beta and intact (EPS CAGR 11%) and with a less
frothy valuation, we raise WTB from Neutral to Buy. Part of our caution on the name this
past 12 months has been the risk of slower LFL growth in the context of tougher
comparatives and a consensus that had moved very bullish. With the stock now trading
Feb17E PE 16x for double digit growth and a c.15% TSR we think it is time to revisit.

11:51 am
BE

Current SP is discounting Premier Inn at 12x PE
With Costa at a 20% PE discount (based on our estimates) to Starbucks (fair given the
scale differential), Pub Restaurants at 9x EV/EBITDA (in line with UK pub peers), the
WTB SP leaves Premier Inn trading on 9x Feb 2017E EV/EBITDA and a PE of 12x. At its
SP highs in 2015 the same approach derived a valuation for Premier Inn of 12x
EV/EBITDA and a PE of 20x.

BE

A well-constructed and proven growth strategy
WTB still offers solid growth driven by LFLs (3-4%), operational gearing to incremental
LFL sales (c.3x) and, new space (5-8% pa,) with a proven track record and strong core
brands. Of group EBIT, 65% is derived from Premier Inn (EBIT +12%pa, ROIC c.12%)
and, 25% from Costa Coffee (EBIT +15%pa, ROIC c.40%), both are UK market leaders.

BE

Valuation - PO unchanged at 5080p, 20% upside potential
Using Feb 2017E we value Premier Inn 12x EV/EBITDA, Pub Restaurants 9x EV/EBITDA
to derive a combined Whitbread Hotel and Restaurant valuation 11x EV/EBITDA or PE
17.5x and, Costa Coffee at 14x EV/EBITDA equal to PE 25x.

11:51 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,180, up 60 (+1.46%), High: 4,216, Low: 4,150, Volume: 420.95k
undefined
PM

There's a full blown Buiter our, but havent had a change to read

11:53 am
PM

Buiter plus Mark Schofield and team, to be exact

PM

In some respects, the start of 2016 brings a sense of deja-vu. We continue to expect central bank divergence, equity markets are jittery and bond yields are trading lower, as they were at the start of 2015. At the time of writing, our blended global rates index is just 0.03% higher than it was a year ago and our global equity index stands unchanged.

PM

Market participants appear hesitant to move in any direction, and it is easy to understand why: Return expectations across asset classes are extremely low while volatility is high. Citi's World Government Bond Index yields just 1.15%, the Broad Investment Grade Index 2.5% and market expectations for equity returns have slumped (although Citi's equity strategists are a little more constructive, forecasting returns of about 13.5% globally in our 2016 Outlook). Against a backdrop of high risk and low expected returns, the opportunity cost of sitting on the sidelines for a few weeks must seem very attractive indeed.

11:53 am
PM

indeed

PM

Despite some similarities to early 2015, there are a number of things that make us more nervous than we were then. Although the FOMC has now engaged, it has not removed uncertainty. Indeed the seeming shift in the reaction function to take more account of global events and market moves has arguably reduced transparency. On top of this, many of the downside risks to global growth that we cited a year ago are surfacing: The EM growth model looks broken. China's economic prospects in particular are giving great cause for concern; outside China at least. World trade remains on a downward trajectory, not just as a result of slowing demand from EM, and protectionism appears to be on the rise (see: Beyond EM's Broken Growth Model).

PM

Political issues are also very much on the radar screens now, with a potentially volatile convergence between rising geo-political tensions and greater socio-political instability (see: 2016 Global Political Outlook: Everything that Rises Must Converge). Certainly there has been increased volatility in markets in response to recent political developments; it remains to be seen whether or not this will translate into a sustained increase in market risk premia. There appears to be a greater risk of this happening with the political game shifting out of the diplomatic sphere and towards increased economic sanctions and direct conflict, both of which have tangible economic consequences.
At the time of writing, our base case is for global GDP growth of 2.8% in 2016, which amounts to roughly 2.5% adjusted for the probable understatement of China’s data. This makes 2016 another year of sluggish global growth, well below the long-run norm. Nor do we expect a significant pickup in growth for 2017, either in advanced economies or China, although there may be a technical bounce in emerging market growth as some of the weakest economies start to level off (see: Prospects for Economies and Financial Markets in 2016 and Beyond).

11:54 am
PM

Risks to our global forecasts probably still lie to the downside, especially for EMs. China continues to struggle with rebalancing its economy. Large sectors of the 'old' economy face significant challenges from excess capacity, leverage and loss of competitiveness. The 'new' service-driven economy is probably growing quite well, but it remains to be seen whether it can continue to grow against a cyclical slowdown in the industrial sectors.
Other emerging markets face pressure from the slowdown in China as well as from slowing global trade. Worryingly, there is increasing evidence of rising protectionism. Weaker currencies may promote pockets of demand, but with many countries having little option other than to let their currencies drift, it seems unlikely that this will be a mainstream source of recovery. There are some areas for optimism, such as inward investment and infrastructure spending, however these are likely to take time to have a noticeable impact.
We see three key monetary policy themes: (1) Fed “lift-off": The Fed may have moved, but the subsequent tightening is likely to be a slow crawl. (2) Divergence: Fed tightening is unlikely to trigger a broad trend of higher policy rates outside the US and the general outlook for monetary policy is still “loose for longer”. (3) Increased acceptance that episodes of negative rates may be part of the “new normal”. The ECB, Riksbank and SNB are all likely to keep their key rates below zero.

BE

(@Penny: indeed they do.)

PM

As noted above, politics is likely to be a significant feature of 2016 with considerably increased temperature in the geo-political arena converging with “new” socio-economic risks. We highlight US elections, the UK’s EU referendum, and German/French politics as key issues to watch in 2016.
With downside risks from EM, low-flation and policy divergence as the key themes for 2016, we are inclined to be cautious and continue to de-risk our recommendations. We are running a DM equity/bond & cash barbell approach. 2016 is likely to be a time to be selective about portfolio risk, not bullish across the board (see: Global Asset Allocation: Outlook for 2016).
We have downgraded our allocation to equities overall and to the US specifically, where the outlook for margins doesn’t inspire. But QE and likely FX weakness keep us overweight the euro area and Japanese equities. We remain underweight emerging market equities and have downgraded emerging market credit. We upgrade US credit after seeing it underperform, but still expect European equities to outperform their credit counterparts. US Treasuries still look attractive to us, in the context of our barbelled portfolio, so we remain at a maximum overweight.

We remain medium-term USD bulls. Our forecasts show further USD gains of 5-6% vs. both G10 and EM FX over 6-12m. USD strength since the lows in 2011 has reflected negatives in the rest of the world and we only see the broader trend ending if and when medium-term sentiment on these other regions turns structurally more positive. The USD has tended to rally in all recent previous global growth recessions back to the early 1980s, possibly reflecting its reserve currency and safe haven status
